reasoning: The critique targets Section 2.3.2’s “abundance → altruism” style consideration. But in the essay this consideration is explicitly presented as limited and is immediately caveated: the authors already discuss linear/positional preferences (status, shrines, rivalry) and note weak evidence that wealth increases altruistic spending. So even if the critique’s point landed, it would only modestly affect the overall position (centrality low). As an objection to that sub-argument, emphasizing dominance/defense as a positional good is directionally relevant, but it overstates: power/dominance being the “most relevant resource,” being strictly zero-sum, and crowding out “any surplus” for altruism are speculative and not established, and the essay’s existing caveats partially absorb the criticism (moderate correctness, limited incremental strength). The critique is clear and focused on one issue, with a small amount of rhetorical dead weight (“economically illiterate”).
title: Power as a positional good prevents the predicted pivot to altruism
